item.notes: The routine devised here calculates "rhythmical tightness," via phonetic tran- scription and the Entropy theorem in information theory. See Kondratov (L1321).

item.bib: -----. "Rhythmical Ordering as a Parameter of Linguistic Style." Pacific Coast Philology 5 (1970): 67-72.
item.notes: A computer program is presented which scans verbal texts for rhythmical or- derliness ("tightness" or "looseness"), the conception of rhythm being based on the Shannon entropy equations in information theory. And though the proce- dure tells us nothing about meter, it does employ the metrical concept of the "foot" in tabulation, and its final rankings of texts (as to degree of rhythmical- ness) match very well our intuitive judgments of "poetry" versus "novel" and "speech." The underlying question raised is whether or not the brain itself de- rives (then predicts) such characteristic curves of rhythmicity for verbal texts. Sample texts are Spanish.

item.notes: To the general Halle-Keyser rule that no Stress Maximum may fall in a W po- sition, Napoli adds one Correspondence Rule specifically for Italian: the first S position in a line is "optionally and frequently" realized by an unstressed sylla- ble. The nursery rhymes are often composed in half-lines, ambiguously iambic or trochaic, the trochaic analysis having some advantage. Also noted are line structures of "metrical nesting" and "metrical mirror-images."
